By a fourth considerationi am led to the same line of defense, “that the mere carriage ol contraband is not such per se, but [it is unlawful], because it would seem to assist in doing a wrong, that is, in giving aid to the Turks. This assistance, since in this case it would be many stages removed, would not imply irregularity, to say nothing of any other criminal ollense. Thus, lor instance, the man who furnishes a remote incentive to homicide would not be guilty of an irregularity. This is literally the reply made by a man ol clear judgment and of eminent erudition and uprightness. To the same ellect Navarrus, who praises the man I have mentioned, lays down the ruling that he who builds triremes lor the Turks gives them a very remote incentive to light the Christians. But to serve on Turkish triremes when they were warring against the Christiane would be to assist directly in doing wrong, and it has been so char· acterized by the canon law. Carrying arms to the Turks would not 89 be a direct wrong nor a wrong at all in this sense, to adopt the dis· tinctions which these very writers make in following others. Have not the Turks today various wars amongst themselves, waged both at the gates of the city and against the Persians? Now, to carry such articles to the Turks as will be very probably used against the Turks is not forbidden, “for no one questions the lawfulness of helping infidels against infidels, as Navarrus and another very learned Spanish scholar, Molina, remark.
